article.headline: California 91, Oregon State 66
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- When Richard Midgley was sidelined with a shoulder injury two weeks ago, it was hard to imagine how California would survive without its leading scorer. But even before Midgley returned on Saturday night, the Golden Bears were playing their best basketball of the season with offensive contributions from all over their roster. Rod Benson had 22 points and 10 rebounds, and Cal scored 20 consecutive points in the first half of a 91-66 victory over Oregon State on Saturday night. Dominic McGuire scored 11 points and Midgley had nine in the highest-scoring performance of the season for the Golden Bears (11-8, 4-5 Pac-10), who have won three straight. They had little trouble beating Oregon State for the 14th straight time -- the longest winning streak in the history of a series dating back to 1915. Cal held the Beavers scoreless for more than 7½ minutes in the first half, turning a five-point deficit into what turned out to be an insurmountable lead. Benson had five points in the 20-0 run, and Midgley had a 3-pointer. "We've just kind of loosened up," said Ayinde Ubaka, who had nine points and four assists. "Coach (Ben Braun) just let us start to make decisions and trust us to go for the right play. We just like playing with each other now." Midgley sat out the previous three games to rest his shoulder. He hit two 3-pointers as Cal swept its home games against the Oregon schools for the seventh straight year. "I'm just trying to fit in now," said Midgley, whose shoulder pain essentially has subsided. "The last couple of games, how well the team has played, I didn't want to come back and mess up what we had." Cal's offense has improved remarkably since Midgley was forced to the sidelines. Benson, Dominic McGuire and freshman DeVon Hardin all scored impressive baskets in the low post, and Midgley's replacements at point guard -- Ubaka and Martin Smith -- combined for 16 points and 11 assists. It all added up to Cal's biggest offensive game since a 91-80 win at Arizona State on Feb. 28, 2002. "There's really a notion from our team that there's a lot of ways to attack," Braun said. "I really enjoy watching our guys play together, and looking at how much they have improved." David Lucas had 22 points and 10 rebounds for the Beavers (11-9, 3-6), who are winless in five conference road games. They have lost six of seven since beating UCLA and USC at home in the opening week of conference play. Though Oregon State has two road victories over Cal in the past decade, the Beavers haven't actually won a game on the court in Berkeley since 1995. They beat the Bears in Oakland in 1998, and got a forfeit victory in 1996 -- but coach Jay John's team gave another dismal effort at Haas Pavilion. "I thought we were really flat," John said. "I didn't like our energy. I can't really explain (why) in my time here, we've been much more competitive against Stanford than Cal. It's a riddle we haven't been able to solve. We just seem to have more juice against Stanford." Vic Remmers had a career-high nine points, but the Beavers made 19 turnovers and allowed 46 points in the paint by Cal. Chris Stephens and Nick DeWitz also scored nine points apiece. Benson scored in double figures for the eighth time in Cal's nine Pac-10 games while also leading the Bears in rebounds for the sixth straight game. The 6-foot-10 junior is one of the nation's most improved players, raising his scoring average by more than 10 points from last season. "I like Rod's activity," Braun said. "He doesn't have to be a scorer for us. He runs the transition, and he puts pressure on the other team's post players."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
